supporting_text: The NAP mentions specific actions in the human health sector, including the prevention and control of infections associated with health care.
The NAP includes actions to prevent and control infections in animal production and companion animals.
The NAP emphasizes the importance of environmental factors in the emergence and spread of antimicrobial resistance.
The NAP addresses the regulation of antimicrobial use in agriculture and promotes sustainable practices.
The NAP outlines the need for annual or biannual operational plans to evaluate and adjust activities.
The NAP sets specific objectives and timelines for various actions related to antimicrobial resistance.
The document does not mention specific budget allocations for the strategies outlined.
The NAP establishes a multisectoral committee involving various ministries for coordination.
The NAP promotes the incorporation of AMR topics into educational curricula and training programs.
The NAP includes plans for public awareness campaigns to inform about the responsible use of antimicrobials.
The NAP acknowledges collaboration with international organizations like WHO and FAO.
The NAP outlines the development of an integrated surveillance system for AMR.
The NAP emphasizes the need for capacity building in detecting and reporting AMR.
The NAP includes strategies for infection control and hygiene measures to prevent AMR.
The NAP refers to the need to align with OIE and FAO standards for antimicrobial use.
The NAP includes regulations for the prescription and distribution of antimicrobials.
The NAP aims to strengthen the regulatory framework for antimicrobial use.
The NAP emphasizes the need for regulations to ensure the rational use of antibiotics.
The NAP encourages participation in international research collaborations for AMR.
